history.content:
I don't know if 70 is really comparable to the 61 series in a meaningful manner, since there is no programming/projects and your grade is pretty much entirely psets or exams (which are fat, timed psets). I had a great time in 70 and abysmal time in 54 so not sure about that one, but the study habits you build in those classes will serve you well in 70 (staying on top of the content week by week is very important, make use of discussion/OH, find a motivating study group). Looking at the course content beforehand is also a great idea! The course moves quite fast to try your very best to stay on top of the content. Another resource that's highly regarded is the IMT decal-- I'm not sure you'll get a chance to actually take the decal before your time in 70 but honestly you don't need to, you can go on the site and read through the notes which give a very beginner-friendly intro to some of the earlier cs70 topics.

I don't want to repeat a ton of advice mentioned before, so if you search "cs70 advice" on this piazza, there's a few past posts that triumph over piazza's subpar search feature. while content varies a little bit semester to semester, general advice is about the same so read through the past posts to get some insight too.

some posts: @11085, @9996, @10957, @9878

----------

It's easier than 61 series, but harder than MATH 54. Key to success is 1) read the lecture notes 2) do the past exams.

I don't know if 70 is really comparable to the 61 series in a meaningful manner, since there is no programming/projects and your grade is pretty much entirely psets or exams (which are fat, timed psets). I had a great time in 70 and abysmal time in 54 so not sure about that one, but the study habits you build in those classes will serve you well in 70 (staying on top of the content week by week is very important, make use of discussion/OH, find a motivating study group). Looking at the course content beforehand is also a great idea! The course moves quite fast to try your very best to stay on top of the content. Another resource that's highly regarded is the IMT decal-- I'm not sure you'll get a chance to actually take the decal before your time in 70 but honestly you don't need to, you can go on the site and read through the notes which give a very beginner-friendly intro to some of the earlier cs70 topics.

I don't want to repeat a ton of advice mentioned before, so if you search "cs70 advice" on this piazza, there's a few past posts that triumph over piazza's subpar search feature. while content varies a little bit semester to semester, general advice is about the same so read through the past posts to get some insight too.

some posts: @11085, @9996, @10957, @9878

I am planning to take CS70 during Fall 2020 and really want to do well. Any tips/suggestions/advice on how to succeed in this class? I am planning to look at the class website and follow along over the summer. Are there any other reccomended resources? What is this class like and how difficult is it compared to CS61A/CS61B/Math54? How much time should I expect the class assignments to take?

Thank you haha
history.subject: CS70 Advice
